skills.name: Use inequality notation to order negative decimals with a different number of digits
Solve one-step linear inequalities in one variable where the variable appears on one side of the equation
Substitute negative integer values into expressions involving no powers or roots
Substitute negative integer values into expressions involving powers or roots
Solve linear inequalities involving two inequality signs

explanations.A: It may be helpful to remember that the inequality sign will always â€˜point toâ€™ the smaller value. Try substituting in the value for ğ‘‘ into each inequality and then deciding which side is smaller, and therefore does this match what is being expressed.

explanations.A: Substituting the value ğ‘‘ = 6 into Inequality 1 gives 3 Ã— 6 â‰¤ 18, which is correct because 18 is less than or equal to 18. Substituting the value ğ‘‘ = 6 into Inequality 2 gives 18 > 6 + 12, which is incorrect because 18 is not greater than 18, but equal to it (which isn't included in this inequality). Therefore only Inequality 1 is valid here.
explanations.B: It may be helpful to remember that the inequality sign will always â€˜point toâ€™ the smaller value, and that there is a difference between inequalities that include the end number (i.e. less than or equal to / greater than or equal to) vs those that do not (i.e. the value must be less than or greater than, but cannot be equal to).
